description: From Middle French jacquet, diminutive of Old French jaque.

entries.meaning: A piece of clothing worn on the upper body outside a shirt or blouse, often waist length to thigh length.
A piece of a person's suit, beside trousers and, sometimes, waistcoat; coat (US)
A protective or insulating cover for an object (e.g. a book, hot water tank, bullet.)

examples: "I need to look up somebody's jacket."

entries.meaning: (military) In ordnance, a strengthening band surrounding and reinforcing the tube in which the charge is fired.
The tough outer skin of a baked potato.
examples: Cook the potatoes in their jackets.

entries.meaning: (Jamaica) A bastard child, in particular one whose father is unaware that they are not the child’s biological father.

verbs.description: jacket (third-person singular simple present jackets, present participle jacketing, simple past and past participle jacketed)

entries.meaning: To confine (someone) to a straitjacket. [from 18th c.]
examples: ‘None of your gab, I tell you! If you speak another word, I'll have you jacketed  […] !’

entries.meaning: (transitive) To enclose or encase in a jacket or other covering. [from 19th c.]
examples: ...to...prevent...the loss of heat...there is also a layer of silicate cotton or slag wool. This latter material is also employed to jacket the chimney for a certain portion of its length.
